Interview Text:
Heather (LGBTQ)

(part 1)

I mention Heather in my book of interviews of people who have stories dealing with LGBT and the church. 
She also told me about moments when she heard from God and it was very transformational for her. 
She was born as a girl but had never lived up to her father's desire to have a "daddy's girl." Instead of wanting to play with dolls and makeup she played with GI Joes and rough-housed with the boys. She also found herself attracted to women. When her church seemed too uncomfortable with these questions she found answers, and the feelings of family she had always lacked, among the LGBT community. They recognized her gender disforia and encouraged her to start transitioning from being a woman to being a man. The process was freeing in a lot of ways. But after she had surgery to remove her breasts she woke up from the surgery and looked down. Instead of feeling happy she felt sad. 
And she started realizing that although her LGBT community had loved her in a lot of ways the church hadn't and the transitioning had given her some new resonance between her body and her feelings, she was still unhappy. And she found herself coping in unhealthy ways such as by abusing food and having codependent relationships.
She eventually prayed with a charismatic ministry and felt like God asked her, "Why are you trying to solve bits and pieces of your problems when I want to heal all of you. If you keep avoiding the root problem you will run from one coping mechanism to the next, never finding true satisfaction."
And she asked, "Do you want me to be a woman or a man? Who do you see me as?"
And she heard, "You are my daddy's girl."
And this is what started transforming her at her core. It is helping her redefine what femininity means for her and hanging close to God as He walks her through what to do daily.
